<title type="main">Ut Pictura Poesis! Or, The Enraged Musician</title>
UT PICTURA POESIS! OR, THE ENRAGED MUSICIAN. A MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

CHARACTERS. Castruccio, Mr. Chambers, Young Quaver, Mrs. Iliff, Knife-Grinder, Mr. Reeve, Cries, Mob, &c. Mr. Mathews, Mr. Johnson, Mr. Chapman, &c. &c. Castruccina, Mrs. Bannister, Picolina, Mrs. Plomer, Milk-Girl, Miss George, Cries, Ballad-Singer, &c. Mrs. Edwin, Mrs. Powell, Mrs. Lefevre, &c.

Overture. A ROOM—Castruccio at the Harpsichord with Castruccina, his Daughter, and Picolina, his Pupil, singing and playing a Trio. After a Time, Castruccio, (interrupting.) Recitativo. Ah! Basta! Basta!—Bene Castruccina! But Dibel take Signora Picolina! All out of tune! my ear—you crack de drum; Vish I was deaf—or vish dat you struck dumb. But let us try once more! Da Capo! come! [Return to the Trio.] Still out of tune! your notes all wild and skittish: Nothing you sing so well as Antient British: In ev'ry tune some Mountain Tricks you bring; Observe your Master, and learn how to sing! Italian Tune—(falsetto.) Come, now begin your Air that seldom fails! So let us hear your Madrigal from Wales. Picolina sings. (The Words by Pope.) “Flutt'ring spread thy purple pinions, “Gentle Cupid, o'er my heart! “I a slave to Love's dominions, “Nature must give way to Art.” Recitativo—Castruccio. Silence, Welch Goats! and Peace, Extravaganza! Come, Castruccina—Taste and Eleganza! Castruccina sings in a different style. (The Words by another Hand.) “Alas, and woe to Fanny! “He has stol'n my heart away; “Do what you will, my Daddy, “He's with me night and day. “His form is still before me, “E'en think of what I may; “Alas, and woe to Fanny! “He has stole my heart away. “Ye spirits of the mountains, “Who've view'd our harmless love, “Ye rocks, ye woods, ye fountains, “Where oft we've lov'd to rove; “Ye blithsome, bounding, birdlings, “Who've heard his melting lay, “Oh sure ye cannot wonder “He has stole my heart away!” Recitativo—Castruccio. Divino! 'tis the musick of the spheres! So very chaste, it ravishes my ears. To-day, a Day of Thanks, with heart and voice, De Commonalty and Great Volk rejoice. Give me de score! mine Ode shall be revis'd: England by me, like Italy, is priz'd; (pino) I'm here John Bull, (forte) because I'm naturaliz'd. (fortissimo) Come, Castruccina! Pic, mine lofe, chime in! Bote follow in due time! mind! I begin. ODE. O vot a happy day is dis, dis, dis! Each heart with joy go pit-a-pat, All bliss! (Cannon heard) Recitativo. Oh Diavolo! vat dat? Women, going on with the Air. Such harmony, such harmony To-day we see— Castruccio, going on. Reign over Thames, and Tweed, and Shannon. Sweet Loyalty! (Cannon.) Recitativo. O dam de cannon! (Cannon) Trio. Castruccio. Again? what a clatter! Run, fly, Castruccina! Away, Picolina! Go see what's the matter! Run, fly! Castruccina. Forbear your alarm! Picolina. You'll come to no harm. (Cannon again.) Castruccio. Again! what a clatter! Go, see what's the matter! Both Women. I haste to obey you—and I, And I; I haste to obey you—and I. [Exeunt, Guns firing. SCENE changes to the Outside of Castruccio's House, as in Hogarth. Enter Young Quaver. Recitativo. Here lives sweet Castruccina! my delight, Who charms my hearing, and transports my sight. What if I now but help to fill a Chorus, Together join'd, we'd carry all before us: Top of the tree she is; and beats them all, In winter here, in summer at Vauxhall. AIR. In Air, Serenata, Plain Song, or Cantata, French, English, Italian, or Dutch; The sweet liquid note That trills from her throat, A soul the most savage must touch. Loud Stentors still bawling, Shrill Misses still squawling, May well, patient sitters, make you sick: Castruccina who hears, Or melts into tears, Or is rapt to the skies with her Musick. Recitativo. But who shall be the bearer of this letter? [Milk below, cried without. Milk-below-Doll! I could not find a better. Enter Milk Girl, with Pails. Sweet Curds and Cream! my dainty pail of Milk! With skin as white as snow, and soft as silk! To old Castruccio's while your pails you bear, Convey these Stanzas to his daughter fair! To her my Venus prove a gentle dove, And bear, sweet Doll, the charming yoke of Love. Milk Girl. Signora Castruccina I know well; In beauty and in voice she bears the bell: And tho', a Nightingale, she charms the throng, She often listens to my humble song. Ballad—The Words by Harry Carey. I. Ye Nymphs and Sylvan Gods, That love green fields and woods, When Spring newly born, Herself loves to adorn, With flowers and blooming buds; In chearful lays Come sing in the praise, Amidst the pleasant vale; Of those that choose Their sleep to lose, And in cold dews, With clouted shoes, Still carry the Milking Pail. II. When cold bleak winds loud roar, And flowers spring no more, The fields lately seen So pleasant and green, By winter all candied o'er; Oh how the Town Lass looks with her white face, And her lips of deadly pale! But it is not so with those that go Thro' frost and snow, with cheeks that glow, To carry the Milking Pail. III. The Miss of courtly mould, Adorn'd with pearl and gold, With washes and paint Her skin does so taint, She's wither'd before she's old: Whilst she in commode puts on a cart-load, And while cushions swell her tail, What joys are found in russet gown, Young, plump and round, and sweet and sound, Along with the Milking Pail! [Exit to Castruccio's with the Letter. Recitativo—Young Quaver. The Note tells Castruccina my intention— (Knives to grind, &c. without. Here comes the Knife-grinder to whet invention. Enter Knife-Grinder. Air. Knives to grind! knives to grind! Penknives, scissars, or razors to grind! Knives, penknives to grind, my good master! Sweet mistresses, scissars to grind! See faster, and faster, and faster, Whrr, whrr, spins the wheel; Ftz, ftz, ftz, sparkles the steel; And I set them to your mind. Recitativo. Knife-Grinder —(seeing Young Quaver.) Ha! are you there, my pretty Master Quaver? What mischief now? for you're a cunning shaver. Young Quaver. Long as that wheel you have been us'd to whirl, You ne'er sound mischief in a pretty girl: To old Castruccio's daughter I aspire, Who meets my hopes, but dreads her crafty sire. Could I but throw him off his guard to-day, Faith, before night, his Ward would run away. Knife-Grinder. Ay! say you so? then I'll secure the Fair; I know Castruccio's humour to a hair: He's like an Ass, all Ear; and only thence Bliss charms his soul, or pain annoys his sense. For sounds, he's like Ben Jonson's Old Morose; Like him we'll plague him with a trick jocose. I'll scour the street, and to his door bring down The various torments of this noisy town, To split his ears, and all his senses drown. Knives to grind, &c. [Exit with his Air. Recitativo.—Y. Quaver. A pleasant trick! our plot's now firmly laid: This suits my own intended Masquerade. But now by gentle Serenade I'll try To bring my lovely Castruccina nigh. At York I play'd Leander; his Duett, Sung in the Padlock, I can ne'er forget. [Begins to sing—soon the Balcony opens, and Castruccina appears, on which he drops the Air, and falls into. Recitativo. But see the Curtain rises! let me run! “It is the East, and Juliet is the Sun!” Castruccina. I've read your lines, and will be ever near; And soon to trim the lamp as you appear, Quickly down stairs shall Castruccina glide; Your light and Hymen's torch shall be my guide. We'll leave awhile Castruccio in the lurch, Till, Bride and Bridegroom, we return from church. Duett. Cruel to part! yet sweet, So soon again to meet! Once gain the happy shore, We meet to part no more! [She draws the Curtain, and he departs. Enter Men and Women, one after another, with different Cries; some with Baskets, some with Trays, some with Wheelbarrows. Cries, without Musick. Knives to grind! Sweep, chimney, sweep! Dust, ho! Potatoes, three pounds for twopence, potatoes! Mackarel, new Mackarel! Flummery! &c. After a Time, Recitativo. Castruccio, (throwing up the window) Confound your noises! choak your throats! To discord you turn all my notes: I'll trounce you all: [Enter Young Quaver as a lamplighter, puts the ladder against the lamp under the window, and in Castruccio's face.] —Oh curse your ladder! Such impudence makes me still madder— But you shall find, you sting an Adder. [He retires a little from the window. In the mean time Castruccina runs out, and goes off with Young Quaver; but not before Castruccio returns to witness their departure. The Mob block up the door, and then follows, Glee. Cas. Oh curse your din! You've shut me in: But you shall know— Cry. Milk below! Cas. A constable! A constable! I will have justice summary. Cry. Flummery, maids! rare flummery! Cas. The villain who my daughter snatches— Cry. Matches! matches! the very best of matches! Cas. The scoundrel shall find— Cry. Knives to grind! Cas. To Bridewell the rascal I'll send. Cry. Pots to mend! pans, kettles to mend! Cas. Oh curse your knell! Cry. Mackarel! Cas. Damnation! hell! Cry. New mackarel! Cas. O very well! Cry. Mackarel! Cas. Base reptiles! rude roysters! Cry. Fine Colchester oysters! Cas. Ye wretched confounders! Cry. Flounders, Thames Flounders! Cas. By Jupiter Ammon! Cry. Fine Newcastle salmon! Cas. The noises you keep— Cry. Sweep, sweep, sweep! [Clattering shovels and brooms. [At the end of the Glee, or before, Quaver and Castruccina return with the drums and marrow-bones and cleavers, and kneel before the window, which enrages Castruccio still more: And the rest of the piece concludes amidst the confusion of drums playing, &c. a girl, with a rattle, little boy with a penny trumpet, old bagpiper, &c. as near as possible to Hogarth's Print of The Enraged Musician. THE END.
